Description: A quality control tool for high throughput raw sequence data.
Features: It generates quality reports for NGS data and gives pass/fail results for the following checks: Per base sequence quality, Per sequence quality scores, Per base sequence content, Per base GC content, Per sequence GC content, Per base N content, Sequence length distribution, Sequence duplication levels, Overrepresented sequences, Kmer content. It also has a Graphic User Interface.
Strength: It is easy to use; provides visualization in HTML reports; can be used on Illumina, PacBio, 454 reads.
{\"value\" : \"single-end\" , \"text\":: single-ended;  {"value":"paired-end", "text":"Apply to forward and reverse strands separately."}

Description: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for short-reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.
Features: The sub-command "fastx_trimmer" can be used to shorten reads (removing barcodes or noise) in FASTQ files . The sub-command "fastqx_clipper" can remove sequencing adapters or linkers.
Strength: Besides "fastx_trimmer" and "fastx_clipper" in this toolkit, there are multiple tools and commands for processing FASTA/FASTQ files. It can also be integrated and used on the web-based bioinformatics platform Galaxy.
Limitation: Last updated in 2010. {"value": "Be ware of the older base quality encoding. ", "link" : "https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/bioiteam/FASTQ+Manipulation+Tools" }

Description: A flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data
Features: It can trim adapter sequences, remove low-quality reads and bases.
Strength: It is designed as more pair-aware for paired-end data. The authors found trimmomatic to run faster than cutadapt and FASTX-Toolkit.  ({"value":"see Trimmomatic paper","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103590/"})

Description: Cutadapt finds and removes adapter sequences, primers, poly-A tails and other types of unwanted sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads.
Features: Cutadapt helps with various trimming tasks by finding the adapter or primer sequences in an error-tolerant way. It can also modify and filter reads in various ways. Adapter sequences can contain IUPAC wildcard characters. Also, paired-end reads and even colorspace data are supported. If you want, you can also just demultiplex your input data, without removing adapter sequences at all ({"value":"see manual","link":"https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/cutadapt/stable/cutadapt.pdf"}).
Strength: It supports 454, Illumina and SOLiD (colour space) data. It is used inside another tool called {"value":"Trim Galore","text":"https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_galore/"}, also a quality control tool by the FastQC team.

Description: An ultrafast memory-efficient short read aligner.
Features: It uses Burrows-Wheeler transform to create a permanent, reusable index of the genome.
Strength: It aligns short DNA sequences (reads) to the human genome at a rate of over 25 million 35-bp reads per hour. Bowtie indexes the genome with a Burrows-Wheeler index to keep its memory footprint small: typically about 2.2 GB for the human genome (2.9 GB for paired-end). {"value":"see Bowtie page", "link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml"} For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and/or more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"link","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Limitation: It does not support gapped alignments; there is an upper limit on read length (1024 bp).
Format_input: FASTQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences.
Features: Bowtie2 first extracts "seed" substrings in reads, aligns seeds in an ungapped way, and then performs extension in a gapped way.
Strength: Bowtie 2 supports gapped, local, and paired-end alignment modes. It indexes the genome with an FM Index to keep its memory footprint small: for the human genome, its memory footprint is typically around 3.2 GB. For reads longer than about 50 bp, Bowtie 2 is generally faster, more sensitive, and uses less memory than Bowtie 1. It is particularly good at aligning reads of about 50 up to 100s or 1,000s of characters, and good at aligning to relatively long (i.e. mammalian) genomes.  {"value":"see Bowtie2 page","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/index.shtml"}
Limitation: For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"see this","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Format_input: FASTQ, QSEQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: BWA is a software package for mapping low-divergent sequences against a large reference genome.
Features: BWA uses a Burrows-Wheeler transform to create an index of the genome. It consists of three algorithms: BWA-backtrack, BWA-SW and BWA-MEM. The first algorithm is designed for Illumina sequence reads up to 100bp, while the rest two for longer sequences ranged from 70bp to 1Mbp. {"value":"link","link":"http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/bwa.shtml"}
Strength: BWA allows indels in alignment. BWA is used by {"value": "GATK best practice for variant discovery", "link": "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/best-practices/workflow?id=11145"}. A special note for {"value": "variant calling from RNA-seq data", "link": "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/best-practices/workflow?id=11164"}: STAR is used by GATK best practices with a 2-pass approach ({"value" : "Engstrom et al. 2013 Nat. Methods", "link" : "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24185836"}).

Description: SAMtools: Utilities for the Sequence AlignmentMap (SAM) format.
Features: SAMtools has multiple commands for processing SAM/BAM files. The sub-command "SAMtools-flagstat" can be used to print statistics for SAM/BAM files using the {"value":"FLAG field","link":"https://samtools.github.io/hts-specs/SAMv1.pdf"}.

Description: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.
Features: As recommended in {"value": "GATK best practice for variant discovery, preprocessing", "link": "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/best-practices/workflow?id=11165"}, PICARD-MergeBamAlignment utilizes readgroup information, merges mapped and unmapped BAM files, and does some extra cleanup.

Description: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.
Features: Picard-MarkDuplicates can be used to remove duplicates, as recommended in As recommended in {"value": "GATK best practice for variant discovery, preprocessing", "link": "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/best-practices/workflow?id=11165"}. Duplicates marked will be ignored by default in GATK.
Limitation: MarkDuplicates uses coordinate information but not read sequence information.

Description: First step of base quality score recalibraton.
Features: Base quality scores of sequencing reads can have systemaic biases from sequencing experiments. BaseRecalibrator is used to build a model of covariation based on the data and a set of known variants. This command needs to be ran twice.
Strength: Base quailty score recalibration is optional but recommended by GATK best practices to correct systematic biases.

Description: Next step of base quality score recalibraton.
Features: ApplyBQSR recalibrates the base qualities of the input reads based on the recalibration table produced by the BaseRecalibrator tool. ApplyBQSR is in GATK4; In GATK3, use the command PrintReads.
Strength: Base quailty score recalibration is optional but recommended by GATK best practices to correct systematic biases.

Description: Create plots to visualize base recalibration results.
Features: After using BaseRecalibrator and ApplyBQSR, AnalyzeCovariates can be ran to plot base quality score recalibration plots.
Strength: Base quailty score recalibration is optional but recommended by GATK best practices to correct systematic biases.

Description: Call germline SNPs and indels via local re-assembly of haplotypes.
Features: The main steps are identifing active regions, assembling plausible haplotypes (Involving local realignment via graph assembly), scoring haplotypes using PairHMM, and determining most likely genotypes.
Strength: In the haplotype assembing step, graph assembly recovers indels and removes artifacts. Note that the genotyping step assumes ploidy of 2 by default. For cohort analysis, HaplotypeCaller can be ran in GVCF mode with a joint genotype calling step using multiple samples in the cohort.
Limitation: The combination between GVCF-based calling or the multisample calling and the RNAseq-specific functionalities have not been fully tested yet. When running, queue rather than multi-threading is recommended.

Description: Perform joint genotyping on gVCF files produced by HaplotypeCaller
Features: It merges GVCF and re-calls the genotypes. Check {"value" : "CombineGVCFs" , "link" : "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/documentation/tooldocs/3.6-0/org_broadinstitute_gatk_tools_walkers_variantutils_CombineGVCFs.php"} or {"value" : "GenomicsDBImport", "link" : "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/documentation/tooldocs/4.0.1.1/org_broadinstitute_hellbender_tools_genomicsdb_GenomicsDBImport.php" } when runing this command.
Strength: The usage of large cohort increases sensitivity.

step: Variant filtering by variant quality score recalibration
Description: A soft filtering way using information from known sites.
Features: It trains a model using high-confidence known sites from resources and callset to determine the probability of a new variant being a real variant. Note that SNP and INDELs shall be recalibrated separately.
Strength: In comparison to hard filtering using binary threshold, it requires less expertise.
Limitation: It requires well-curated known resources (like HapMap) with confident variants. Note: if calling variants from WES data, sample size larger than 30 and usage of resources like 1000G is recommended. Useful only for non-human organisms where resourses are lacking. Not recommended for variant calling using RNA-seq data.

step: Variant filtering by variant quality score recalibration
Description: Apply a score cutoff to filter variants based on a recalibration table
Features: The next step of VariantRecalibrator for soft filtering of raw variants called.
Limitation: A choice of sensitivity is required.

Description: Calculate genotype posterior likelihoods given panel data.
Features: Improve genotype calls and likelihoods using prior knowledge from populational data (e.g. 1000G) and pedigree data (if available).
Strength: The genotype refinement step yields more high-quality genotypes.

Description: Filtering ambiguous or low-confidence calls.
Features: The next step of CalculateGenotypePosteriors. Recommended threshold is GQ = 20

Description: Annotate variant calls with context information and generate De Novo variants.
Features: The next step of VariantFiltration variant context annotation.
Strength: Various annotation module are available. Check the Annotation Modules {"value" : "here", "link" : "https://software.broadinstitute.org/gatk/documentation/tooldocs/3.8-0/org_broadinstitute_gatk_tools_walkers_annotator_VariantAnnotator.php#VariantAnnotations"}.

Description: A variant annotation and effect prediction tool.
Features: Another option besides VariantAnnotator. It annotates and predicts the effects of genetic variants on genes and proteins (such as amino acid changes).
Strength: Various annotation are available. Check {"value": "here", "link": "http://snpeff.sourceforge.net/"}. GATK compatible. It uses sequence ontology standardized terms.
Platform requirement: JAVA; At least 4Gb of memory for human genome.

Description: Comparing statistics between your callset and external resources, on variants level.
Features: Examples of evaluation includes: number of INDELs & SNPs, INDEL ratio and (TiTv) Transitions/Transversions ratio.
Strength: VariantEval has more options than CollectVariantCallingMetrics.
Limitation: Note the importance to match dataset properties like population ethnicity, sequencing techniques, and cohort size.

Description: Comparing statistics between your callset and external resources, on genotype level.
Features: An example of evaluation metric is genotype concordance.
Limitation: Note the importance to match dataset properties like population ethnicity, sequencing techniques, and cohort size.

Description: Comparing statistics between your callset and external resources, on variants level.
Strength: Performs well on very large callsets.
Limitation: Note the importance to match dataset properties like population ethnicity, sequencing techniques, and cohort size.

Description: Comparing statistics between your callset and external resources, on genotype level.
Limitation: Note the importance to match dataset properties like population ethnicity, sequencing techniques, and cohort size.
